articles.headline: Facebook Ads Offer Peek at Looming Supreme Court Fight
articles.snippet: Even before President Trump’s new Supreme Court nominee is announced, partisan groups have flooded Facebook and other social networks with political ads over the pick.
articles.abstract: Even before President Trump’s new Supreme Court nominee is announced, partisan groups have flooded Facebook and other social networks with political ads over the pick.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even before President Trump’s new Supreme Court nominee is announced, a fight over the choice is raging on social media.

articles.headline: Despite State Blessing, Marijuana Dispensaries Face Local Rancor
articles.snippet: More than half of all states have approved marijuana for medical uses, yet winning over landlords and neighbors is an uphill battle for dispensaries.
articles.abstract: More than half of all states have approved marijuana for medical uses, yet winning over landlords and neighbors is an uphill battle for dispensaries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Finding a place to house a medical marijuana dispensary is rarely an easy task, but MariMed Advisors, which specializes in developing cannabis businesses, encountered especially aggressive pushback working for a client in Annapolis, Md., last year.

articles.headline: Trump Voters May Be the Biggest Losers From Trump’s Auto Tariffs
articles.snippet: European auto manufacturers are among the biggest employers in some Republican strongholds.
articles.abstract: European auto manufacturers are among the biggest employers in some Republican strongholds.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — President Trump has complained about seeing too many German cars on Fifth Avenue, and threatened heavy tariffs on the companies that produce them. There is a good chance, though, that those Mercedes-Benzes and BMWs were not only made in the United States, but made by workers who voted for Mr. Trump.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley’s Giants Take Their Talent Hunt to Cambridge
articles.snippet: A boom in artificial intelligence research has drawn the tech industry’s biggest companies and their checkbooks to the storied English city.
articles.abstract: A boom in artificial intelligence research has drawn the tech industry’s biggest companies and their checkbooks to the storied English city.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, England — When you step off the train here and walk into the city square outside the railway station, you will not see the spires of King’s College Chapel or the turrets atop the Trinity Great Court. The University of Cambridge is still a cab ride away. But you will see a stone and glass office building with a rooftop patio. This is where Amazon designs its flying drones.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz and Adam Satariano

articles.headline: Poland Purges Supreme Court, and Protesters Take to Streets
articles.snippet: Demonstrations erupted in dozens of cities across the country as the right-wing governing party consolidated its power and escalated a clash with the European Union.
articles.abstract: Demonstrations erupted in dozens of cities across the country as the right-wing governing party consolidated its power and escalated a clash with the European Union.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Poland’s government carried out a sweeping purge of the Supreme Court on Tuesday night, eroding the judiciary’s independence, escalating a confrontation with the European Union over the rule of law and further dividing this nation. Tens of thousands took to the streets in protest.

articles.headline: On Martha’s Vineyard, a Frosty Summer for Alan Dershowitz
articles.snippet: Mr. Dershowitz says some in the Vineyard, the summer epicenter of progressive values and Democratic power, are shunning him for his views in support of President Trump.
articles.abstract: Mr. Dershowitz says some in the Vineyard, the summer epicenter of progressive values and Democratic power, are shunning him for his views in support of President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHILMARK, Mass. — For years, Alan Dershowitz, the lawyer and professor emeritus at Harvard Law School, has been a garrulous fixture in this handsome, gray-shingled town on Martha’s Vineyard. He holds court from a rocking chair on the porch at the Chilmark General Store, drinking coffee and greeting fellow regulars. He strolls down Lucy Vincent Beach, gabbing on his cellphone along the way.
articles.byline: By Jess Bidgood and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Two Judges Exemplify the Choice Trump Faces in a Supreme Court Pick
articles.snippet: The stark contrast between Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh and Judge Amy Coney Barrett reflects the division on the right between the conservative legal establishment and social conservatives.
articles.abstract: The stark contrast between Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh and Judge Amy Coney Barrett reflects the division on the right between the conservative legal establishment and social conservatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One is a creature of Washington with two Yale degrees, a ticket-punching résumé that includes stints in the Justice Department, the Bush White House and a federal appeals court, where he has written some 300 opinions.

articles.headline: Wang Jian, Co-Founder of Chinese Giant HNA, Dies in France
articles.snippet: The death of a key figure in the company’s rise as a global conglomerate comes as it grapples with high debt after a huge shopping spree.
articles.abstract: The death of a key figure in the company’s rise as a global conglomerate comes as it grapples with high debt after a huge shopping spree.
articles.lead_paragraph: The co-chairman and co-founder of HNA Group, a Chinese conglomerate that spent heavily in recent years to build a global profile but that has since grappled with high debt, died from an accidental fall in France, the company said on Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li

articles.headline: Why Made in China 2025 Will Succeed, Despite Trump
articles.snippet: The modernization push will proceed even if the White House finds a way to hinder the Beijing-led effort to propel its businesses into the next century.
articles.abstract: The modernization push will proceed even if the White House finds a way to hinder the Beijing-led effort to propel its businesses into the next century.
articles.lead_paragraph: China will succeed in building a powerful technology industry that will rival the United States, even if President  Trump starts a trade war to stop it. The reason can be found on the fourth floor of a nondescript factory in a city once famous for cheap manufacturing and prostitution.

articles.headline: Employee Uprisings Sweep Many Tech Companies. Not Twitter.
articles.snippet: Many tech workers are forcing their employers to reconsider how their products are being used by the federal government. When will that activism begin at Twitter?
articles.abstract: Many tech workers are forcing their employers to reconsider how their products are being used by the federal government. When will that activism begin at Twitter?
articles.lead_paragraph: Workers across the technology industry are forcing their employers to reconsider how their products are being used by the United States government.
